description:
John Batchelor March 29,2016
MP3
Putinâ€™s Victory at Palymra. Stephen F. Cohen. NYU, Princeton. EastWestAccord.com.


â€œAfter ten grueling months of ISIS occupation, the ancient city of Palmyra has been liberated. Syrian government troops, backed by Russian air support, encircled Islamic State militants, forcing them to flee into the interior eastern desert. With the extremists gone, experts have had the opportunity to perform a preliminary assessment of the damage inflicted upon the UNESCO World Heritage site. The news is both good and bad.

â€œAccording to Syrian archaeologist Maamoun Abdelkarim, 80 percent of the artifacts in Palmyra appear to be largely intact. There is extensive damageâ€”make no mistakeâ€”but many of the iconic columns remain upright, along with several key temples and monuments. Speaking to the LA Times, Abdelkarim said that thereâ€™s damage to the streets, baths, and some temple fences, but â€œthe panoramic view that tourists know of Palmyra remains.â€ Encouragingly, he said that a significant portion of the restoration work could take just five years.

â€œIslamic State militants occupied the historic city last May, and they took it upon themselves to destroy some of the cityâ€™s most distinctive monuments, including the Arch of Triumph, the Baalshamin Temple, and the Temple of Bel. They chiseled away the faces of statues and reliefs, declaring them blasphemous pagan icons. The militants also beheaded and crucified Khaled Asaad, a prominent Syrian archaeologist. The vandalism inflicted onto Palmyra, an important stop for traders moving between China, India, Persia, and the Roman Empire during the first and second centuries AD, was greeted with global outrage, leading some to declare the actions of ISIS a serious war crimeâ€¦.â€
